title: Erdős #977: Greatest Prime Factor of 2^n - 1
description: Does P(2^n - 1)/n → ∞? Solved by Stewart (2013): P(2^n - 1) ≥ n^{1 + 1/(104 log log n)}. Schinzel (1962) proved P(2^n - 1) > 2n for n > 12.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Andrzej Schinzel, Cameron Stewart

overview.historicalContext: Erdős asked whether P(2^n - 1)/n → ∞, where P(m) is the greatest prime factor. Schinzel (1962) proved P(2^n - 1) > 2n for n > 12. Stewart gave conditional results in 1974 and finally proved the full result unconditionally in 2013 with a quantitative bound.
overview.problemStatement: If P(m) is the greatest prime divisor of m, then is it true that P(2^n - 1)/n → ∞ as n → ∞?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the greatest prime factor function, Mersenne numbers, Stewart's theorem (2013), Schinzel's bound (1962), specific small cases, Mersenne primes, the related P(n!+1) question (still open), Zsygmondy's theorem on primitive prime factors, and the connection to multiplicative order.
keyInsights: Zsygmondy: 2^n - 1 has primitive prime factor for n > 6
Related: P(n! + 1) question is still OPEN

sections.title: Mersenne Primes
sections.summary: When M_n is prime, P(M_n) = M_n

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #977 on the greatest prime factor of Mersenne numbers. Stewart (2013) proved P(2^n - 1)/n → ∞ with the quantitative bound P(2^n - 1) ≥ n^{1 + 1/(104 log log n)}. The related question about P(n! + 1) remains open.
conclusion.implications: Understanding the largest prime factors of 2^n - 1 connects to the structure of Mersenne numbers, primitive prime factors (Zsygmondy), and multiplicative orders. The techniques extend to other exponential sequences.
openQuestions: Can the constant 104 in Stewart's bound be improved?
What is the typical size of P(2^n - 1) for random n?
